displayed_text: Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –

Patient: For what I have. Doctor: …this one, for prostate cancer, is to start with Taxotere or Docetaxel and that would be what you would get. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: One of the things to consider is you know we do have a new hormonal therapy that is being tested and that would be one potential option for you to look into. Patient: Is that a study? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Clinical study? Doctor: Yeah it’s a clinical trial a hormonal agent that has at least three clinically shown promising results. Patient: And that would be here? Doctor: Then it would have to be. Family Member: So that’s different… Doctor: That’s one option.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: just says less than, the less than sign. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Zero point one. We sometimes call it a zero amongst ourselves or undetectable Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We know that there is a very tiny, negligible microscopic level and say meaning that there are cancer cells left behind. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: And so those are the cells that over time, as I said over an average of three to five years end up coming back, or returning and that’s what’s called - Family Member: Despite the hormone therapy. Doctor: Despite the hormone therapy. Family Member: So you can’t like change it, modify it, up it, lower it or whatever? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Do you want to do it in two months or three months? Do you have any preference? Patient: Well when am I going to see you again? Doctor: January would be reasonable. How about three months from now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do it about a week or two before? If I see you in mid-January? Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yes, so again, with the caveat that it would be considered unconventional therapy – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - you know given that caveat if we both acknowledge that, I would be willing to consider that for you, especially if the studies don’t show any disease or metastatic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: disease is one. And if we were both informed that this is really not the conventional therapy and yet you still want to or agree to do it. But I think as long as it’s an informed decision, I’m willing to consider that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It may potentially lessen the side effects if you do it that way without the Lupron at the same time. Patient: Yeah, yeah. For some reason the Lupron, that just knocks me out. For some reason I forget a lot of things, hallucination; I get a Doctor: Great, now when would you like to check the next PSA level and when would you like to do it? Patient: Now next PSA, now did you place an order for mine? Doctor: I did.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, a biologic, so not a chemo. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many, many arms of this trial. It’s like the octopus study. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where there’s a lot. But you’re basically taking a pill. There is a pathway that’s always screwed up with prostate cancer. This sort of tackles that pathway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness.

Patient: I know. I know. Doctor: You feel it too, I’m sure. Patient: You get the PSA yet? Doctor: Not yet. But last time it was going down. Patient: It was one, one, yeah. Doctor: So it went from one point one. Yeah. Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan? Doctor: Oh, (sigh) Patient: Do I have to wait to see it? Doctor: No. I don’t think you need to. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Because, you know, everything’s going okay, and, uh- Patient: But if you see something, you’ll call me?

Patient: Yeah and then I was reading one time that um this is some article published on the on the internet, of course everything on the internet is true. Doctor: Of course you know it’s true. Patient: It says that Lupron um puts the weight on around here. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I thought well that explains why I can’t get rid of it. Patient: But I mean you know. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: If your choice is to have the weight on there or to be a memory I guess I’ll take the weight and work with that. Patient: How have you been? Doctor: Okay. Just running around. Giving more trials and you know keep going. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um I think you know you look great so we need to just come up with… Patient: I feel pretty good.

Patient: Um, that’s it. Doctor: Uh, last time you talked to C_ about your fatigue at the end of the day. Patient: Eh, just tired at the end, at the end, after working all day. Doctor: Any pain anywhere? Patient: No. Doctor: Any belly pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have bleeding, bruising? Patient: No. Doctor: And any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. Bowels are moving

Patient: It doesn’t add up. Family Member: It really doesn’t. It just doesn’t, so. Doctor: So, I forgot, I was actually gonna check that and I will, I forgot but I will do that. I have to figure out how to do that with the – either the operating room or the pathology department. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Maybe the operating room would be first to find out if – I can’t look up another patient’s record that doesn’t belong to me, - Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: -but I can find out if somebody… Family Member: Was scheduled the same day or something. Doctor: But I assume that’s not the case, but I’ll just double check. Patient: Alright. Family Member: Okay. (sighs)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m changing all of that. Patient: Oh, you’re gonna change that? Doctor: Yes, yes. So, October fourth, you’ll just go to chemo directly, to the labs and chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then October twenty-fifth, you’ll see me and get chemo. Patient: Okay. Okay. So, just Doctor: Okay. You need the oxycodone and the walker. Patient: And the, uh, Xanax. Doctor: What is the third script? Patient: My Xanax. That’s it here. So, I’ll need, need that, right. Doctor: Let me see when I gave you the Xanax last. (Pause)

Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Still if you cough or pick up a heavy weight – Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - still even a few years from now maybe a drop or two might come out. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Hmm, okay. (Pause) Doctor: It means that um there’s not enough prostate cancer cells to be detectable by the blood test. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There could either be zero or there could be some somewhere. It’s just not enough for it to be detectible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So therefore getting a CAT scan, bone scan, it doesn’t, it’s kind of a waste of time because even if something’s there it’s not enough to actually be seen. Family Member: Be seen, okay. Doctor: On a scan.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine. Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay.

Patient: Okay. Yeah. Doctor: So this is ascorbic acid is Vitamin C. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: In this docetaxel. So you could use this as material just even docetaxel. It tells you what the side effects are, how often you need to be. The Vitamin C is the experimental part of it. So this would again be intensive to get it done here, but that’s an option. And so this is the one about the immune inhibitors for ARV7 positive tumors and you have to be on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: And this is going to talk about how often you need to be here, what are the side effects, can we get you know the things like that. So this is homework to read to sort of say, “Hey, I would never consider that. There’s too many things going on, I would never do it. Or you know okay it sounds reasonable. Dr. G___ likes it, you like it.” And then we would have that possibility that once we’ve decided you’re no longer benefiting, we will keep you on the Enzalutamide and then we would sort of build this for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes.
